conbody.p: It is up to the editor to decide whether to reconstruct a word/phrase or not. If you are able to reconstruct the missing part(s), e.g. from parallel texts or recurring phrases, use Brackets. If you can reconstruct the lacuna's word class, then use a "representative" (see below).

p.b: General representation of gaps and lacunas

conbody.p: If words or even the number of missing words cannot be reconstructed, represent the lacuna with the following notations:

ul.li: The marker "--...--" with two hyphens is reserved for damaged parts and cannot be lemmatized.

li.p: “--nQ--“ with “n” as the number of destroyed quadrats (see examples below).

ul.li: Complete destruction at the end of a line/column: “--Rest der Zeile/Kolumne zerstört--".
Complete destruction at the beginning of a line/column: “--Anfang der Zeile/Kolumne zerstört--".
Complete destruction of the rest of the text: “--Rest des Textes zerstört--".
If there are traces of signs that cannot be identified, use: "--Zeichenreste--".

conbody.p: NOTE: Between two "--" you cannot write any further hyphens ("-"): write "--4 bis 5Q--", and not "--4-5Q--".

If the number of words missing can precisely be determined (e.g. if the words are completely lost, but their determinatives preserved), use three underscores in brackets "[___]". E.g.: "[___] [___]" for 2 missing words. These representations are treated as words by BTS and can be lemmatized.

In some cases, the missing word's word class, number, and gender can be determined. There are entries in the lemma list for each of these options; you have to search the WCN number via the magnifying glass (see ). For a list of the relevant WCN numbers, see , or alternatively you can search for "[Wort]" (full text search with both check-boxes deactivated) and the list will appear at the bottom of the results.
